title: Synthetic Recap
body:
LOS ANGELES (AP) — In a season often defined by its parity, the Washington Bullets were treated to a performance for the ages. Chris Webber, with the weight of a franchise on his broad shoulders, didn’t just carry his team; he authored a masterpiece, dropping a historic 45 points to power the Bullets past the Los Angeles Clippers, 102-93.

From the opening tip, this was the Chris Webber Show at the Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena. The Clippers had no answer for the versatile big man, who attacked from every conceivable angle. He was a force in the paint, a nightmare in transition, and a one-man offensive system. While teammates like Juwan Howard (15 points) provided crucial support, the night belonged unequivocally to Webber. His 45-point eruption wasn't just scoring; it was a statement.

The Clippers, fighting to the end, were led valiantly by Loy Vaught's 21 points and 15 rebounds, a stellar effort that was simply overshadowed. Rodney Rogers added 19 points, but every Clipper rally was met with a cold-blooded response from Webber. Whether it was a silky jumper or a powerful drive to the rim, he had the answer.

In the annals of Bullets history, this night will be remembered not for the final score, but for the singular dominance of one man. Chris Webber’s 45-point tour de force was more than a win; it was a legendary performance that reminded everyone in attendance of the breathtaking heights a single player can reach.
